mn152:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kajaṅgalā in a bamboo grove.
mn152:2.1: Then the brahmin student Uttara, a pupil of the brahmin Pārāsariya, approached the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
mn152:2.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
mn152:2.3: “Uttara, does Pārāsariya teach his disciples the development of the faculties?”
mn152:2.6: “Master Gotama, it’s when the eye sees no sight and the ear hears no sound.
mn152:2.7: That’s how Pārāsariya teaches his disciples the development of the faculties.”
mn152:2.8: “In that case, Uttara, a blind person and a deaf person will have developed faculties
mn152:2.10: For a blind person sees no sight with the eye and a deaf person hears no sound with the ear.”
mn152:2.11: When he said this, Uttara sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
mn152:3.1: Knowing this, the Buddha addressed Venerable Ānanda,
mn152:3.2: “Ānanda, the development of the faculties taught by Pārāsariya is quite different from the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One.”
mn152:3.3: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One.
mn152:3.4: Let the Buddha teach the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
mn152:3.5: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn152:4.2: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, liking, disliking, and both liking and disliking come up in them.
mn152:4.4: ‘Liking, disliking, and both liking and disliking have come up in me.

mn152:4.12: In the training of the Noble One this is called the supreme development of the faculties regarding sights known by the eye.

mn152:10.1: And how are they a practicing trainee?
mn152:10.2: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, liking, disliking, and both liking and disliking come up in them.
mn152:10.3: They are horrified, repelled, and disgusted by that.
mn152:10.4: When they hear a sound with their ears …
mn152:10.5: When they smell an odor with their nose …
mn152:10.6: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
mn152:10.7: When they feel a touch with their body …
mn152:10.8: When they know a thought with their mind, liking, disliking, and both liking and disliking come up in them.
mn152:10.9: They are horrified, repelled, and disgusted by that.
mn152:10.10: That’s how they are a practicing trainee.
mn152:11-15.1: And how are they a noble one with developed faculties?
mn152:11-15.2: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, liking, disliking, and both liking and disliking come up in them.
mn152:11-15.3: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive,’ that’s what they do.
mn152:11-15.4: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.

mn152:11-15.7: If they wish: ‘May I meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, rejecting both the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.

mn152:17.1: So, Ānanda, I have taught the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One, I have taught the practicing trainee, and I have taught the noble one with developed faculties.
mn152:18.1: Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.
mn152:18.2: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, Ānanda! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”
mn152:18.3: That is what the Buddha said.
mn152:18.4: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.
